thread.title: Josh Huff's breakout game a potentially big sign for Eagles' offense going forward
thread.title_full: Josh Huff's breakout game a potentially big sign for Eagles' offense going forward | NJ.com

author: Eliot Shorr-Parks | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Josh Huff's breakout game a potentially big sign for Eagles' offense going forward
text:
PHILADELPHIA -- Trailing the New Orleans Saints in a must-win game Sunday, the Eagles ' offense was coming off of an interception in the red zone, and was sputtering, much like it had the first month of the season.
Then, on 2nd-and-7 at the beginning of the second quarter, quarterback Sam Bradford found Josh Huff over the middle.
41-yards later, Huff was flipping into the end zone, and the Eagles' offense was off and running.
"I haven't done that since high school," Huff said with a smile of the flip. "I thought it would be fun."
Could it be a sign of things to come?
Huff, a second-year receiver, finally had the breakout game he has been waiting for in the Eagles' 39-17 win over the Saints , finishing with a team-high 78 yards and a touchdown on four catches.
After just playing four snaps in last weekend's loss to the Washington Redskins, Huff was targeted five times Sunday.
"I just prepare like I'm going to get my number called," Huff said. "Today, my number was called and I was able to make the most of my opportunities."
Huff did just that against the Saints, running hard after the catch and looking like the explosive player he did during training camp.
BRADFORD: Report card from win over Saints The fact that it took Huff this long to break out, five games into the season, was one of the weirder subplots to the Eagles' season thus far. Huff started out with the first-team offense during training camp, and slowly saw his role decrease to an afterthought in an offense that was struggling.
His lack of a role in the offense was clearly frustrating to Huff, but after the win, head coach Chip Kelly sounded like a man who knew a big game was coming.
"We believe a good week of training, you sink to your level of training, and your level of training allows you to play well on Sunday," said Kelly. "He had a good week of training and that allowed him to play well. I thought he did a really nice job for us."
Having Huff turn in a big game was a potentially major development for the Eagles' offense.
One of the many issues for the Eagles' offense through the first four games of the season, prior to their win on Sunday, was the lack of big plays from their wide receivers. The unit was dropping passes, not getting open and not making plays when given the chance.
On Sunday, the entire unit did a solid job, and having a more balanced attack -- including the emergence of Huff -- as opposed to having to continually force the ball to wide receiver Jordan Matthews was likely why.
"I would say so. We were able to get the ball going on the ground and in the air," Huff said on if this was the kind of game the offense needed. "We had a balanced attack, we were able to get our running backs involved and we spread the ball around. It was fun."
Fun is something Huff hasn't been having, but that changed on Sunday, from being on the field to doing flips into the end zone.
If Huff can continue to make an impact, the Eagles' offense could slowly start to become the dangerous unit it was supposed to be.
"That's been my goal ever since the season started," Huff said. "I've prepared every week like I was going to have my number called."
